text: today's recipe is kind of fun it's a
homemade vanilla pudding I am not using
a box I know I know I never use a box
I'm making it from scratch it's a creamy
and fantastic recipe with pure vanilla
extract thickened with cornstarch and
with egg yolks for just a little bit of
extra richness I just separated two eggs
I don't need the whites over here at the
stove in this medium saucepan I have a
half a cup of sugar and then to that I'm
adding 3 tablespoons of cornstarch
that's our primary thickener the egg
yolks are sort of a secondary thickener
and they add richness as well an eighth
of a teaspoon of fine salt if you're
using coarse you can use 1/4 teaspoon
whisk that together just make sure
everything is fully combined and then
you can whisk in your milk and cream
it's 1/2 a cup of heavy cream the stove
is not on yet you can whisk your wet
ingredients together off the stove if
you want to in a separate bowl but I
just like to save on bowls and I do it
right here in the pan one and a half
cups of milk whole milk and your two egg
yolks whisk everything so that all your
sugar and cornstarch is completely
dissolved then cook over a medium high
heat until it's thickened and bubbling
that could take 8 to 12 minutes
depending on your stove don't stop
whisking because the cornstarch could
thicken on the bottom of your pot and
then it could scorch so keep whisking
until it gets thick
it's getting thick it looks really good
we also have some other great variations
on the website at Martha Stewart comm if
you want something other than vanilla
when it's bubbling in the center you
know it's done the cornstarch has been
fully activated so this will set in the
refrigerator you can strain through
sieve to remove any pieces if there are
any of cooked egg or any lumps that may
have formed which of course would not
happen because I was so whisking the
entire time but better safe than sorry
this is a pretty fine sieve
I see no lumps a final touch add a
couple tablespoons of unsalted butter it
should be soft so that it just melts
right in there and a teaspoon of pure
vanilla extract whisk so that the butter
melts and the vanilla is combined into
your pudding vanilla is pretty waft of
all getting a nice waft of vanilla
are you a skin on your pudding person
because if you are you can put it into
the refrigerator just like this and the
skin will form but if not press some
plastic wrap directly to the surface
before putting it away when you're ready
to eat and your pudding is fully chilled
you can remove your plastic wrap or if
you didn't use plastic wrap that's fine
too spoon your pudding into a bowl I
like to have mine with a little bit of
whipped cream so I've whipped up some
cream don't have your whipped cream out
of a can either if you're making
homemade pudding
make some homemade whipped cream with a
spoon of your cream and for a finishing
touch why not just a little bit of a
dusting of cocoa powder completely
optional but then you get a little
chocolate a little vanilla and a lot of
fantastic homemade Bayou creamy
delightful pudding
hmm you're not gonna stop
